source.raw_text:
The Jefferson Curl works the entire posterior chain (hamstrings, glutes, erector spinae, calves) and core, emphasizing spinal articulation through controlled vertebral flexion (forward bending), improving mobility, resilience, and end-range strength in the spine and hamstrings, while strengthening the back eccentrically as you lower and concentrically as you lift. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Muscles Worked 

• Posterior Chain: Hamstrings, glutes, calves, erector spinae (lower and upper back). 
• Core: Deep spinal stabilizers, promoting trunk control. [1, 3, 4]  

Movement Pattern: Controlled Spinal Articulation 

1. Setup: Stand on a raised surface (box, step) holding a light weight (kettlebell/dumbbell) with straight arms, feet hip-width apart, knees locked. 
2. Descent (Eccentric): Tuck chin to chest, then slowly roll down one vertebra at a time, rounding the spine segment by segment (upper back, mid-back, lower back), pushing the weight forward to deepen the stretch. 
3. Bottom: Reach the weight forward, pause briefly, and breathe calmly. 
4. Ascent (Concentric): Uncurl back up one vertebra at a time, reversing the motion from the lower back up to the neck. [3, 5, 6, 7, 8]  

Key Aspects 

• Loaded Stretch: It's a deep, loaded stretch for the hamstrings and spine. 
• Spinal Mobility: Enhances flexibility and control through spinal flexion and extension. 
• Eccentric Strength: Builds strength in the back muscles as they lengthen under load. 
• Progressive: Start with bodyweight or very light weight, prioritizing form over load, and gradually increase weight or range of motion. [2, 3, 4, 6, 9]
